This is one of Hong Kong's busiest temples, with most visitors coming to the temple in search of a spiritual answer via a practice called Kau Cim. They light incense sticks, kneel before the main altar, make a wish and shake a bamboo cylinder containing fortune sticks until a stick falls out. A ritual follows and eventually a stick is exchanged for a piece of paper bearing the same number, whereupon the soothsayer will interpret the fortune on the paper for the worshipper. This is a very busy place, particularly during Chinese New Year, with worshippers waiting overnight to get to light their incense as early into the New Year as they can. From here we move onto the peaceful Nan Lian garden and through the Buddhist temple at the Chi Lin Nunnery. This beautiful building was constructed without using any iron nails, as it would have been in the Tang dynasty. It is the only such building in Hong Kong. We finish the tour here, by sharing lunch at the vegetarian restaurant in the garden.
strTitle: See How Feng Shui Has Shaped Hong Kong and Visit Key Temples

strIntroduction: When the British took possession of Hong Kong Island in 1841, it was derogatorily referred to “as a barren rock with scarcely a house upon it” by the British Foreign Secretary, Lord Palmerston. However, the area a few kilometres to the north beyond the Kowloon Hills – after 1898 to be known as the New Territories – was a different matter. In this area, the fertile plains dissected by hills had, for centuries, been settled and farmed by migrant peoples who had moved south from inland China. Five dominant clans were involved in this migration and settlement. The first of these clans was the Tang family who are said to have arrived in the Kam Tin area as early as 973 AD, having moved south from Jiangxi Province. This tour follows their traces. Members of the Tang family established two villages, Shui Tau Tsuen (Water Head Village) and Shui Mei Tsuen (Water Tail Village) in the early 12th century, both just north of the Kam Tin River. These are probably the oldest extant villages in Hong Kong. Despite development and destruction of the landscape around these old villages, several buildings of historical and cultural interest have been left extant. These include temples, clan halls and study halls that contain fine examples of woodwork and decorative pottery. The Yi Tai study hall at Shui Tau Tsuen is a particularly fine example of its kind. We will also visit one of the best examples of a walled village in HK: Kat Hing Wai, which was established in the 15th century. From Kam Tin we drive to Yuen Long to walk the Ping Shan Heritage Trail. One of the highlights of the trail is the Tang Si Chung Ancestral Hall, built about 700 years ago. It is the main ancestral hall of the Tang clan in Ping Shan and is still used for worship, festivals and ceremonies, and clan meetings. The only ancient pagoda in HK, the Tsui Sing Lau Pagoda, will mark the end of our tour. Built more than 600 years ago for fung shui purposes, it was meant to counter destructive forces from the north (floods & evil spirits!), and to ensure clan’s success in imperial examinations.
strTitle: Visit the Fascinating Heritage Sites of the New Territories

strIntroduction: For a great introductory tour to Hong Kong, we will give you a guided history tour of the Central district of Hong Kong Island that explains the colourful background to this region. The future meets the past in Hong Kong and nowhere can you see this more clearly than in the Central district. Our walking tour takes you among historic buildings that are nestled amid stunning skyscrapers, where the ancient art of feng shui influences modern architecture, and along streets whose very names evoke the colourful history of Hong Kong. The heart of Hong Kong city, the Central district, has been developing since inception of British rule in 1841. Western-style buildings sprang up as the city grew prosperously and the early 20th century saw Hong Kong develop into a metropolis. Extensive reclamations extending the waterfront and development projects were carried out during different periods and although the outlook of Hong Kong is ever changing, many historical buildings and structures still survive as standing testimony to the history of Hong Kong Island's Central district. As we walk we admire architecture from well-known architects such as Lord Norman Foster, IM Pei and Kohn Pedersen Fox. Highlights of our guided walk include: Statue Square - over which a seated bronze statue of Queen Victoria once reigned. Within the square stands the elegant and modern HSBC – the fourth HSBC building to occupy the site over a period of 150 years. Built in the early 1980s by Lord Norman Foster, it is a fascinating example of how feng shui and modern environmental features have been merged in present-day Hong Kong. One of Hong Kong’s last remaining colonial buildings. Built from Kowloon granite in the neoclassical style, this elegant and historic building once served as the Supreme Court and is situated on reclaimed land. The Court of Final Appeal - a building of historic importance in Hong Kong. The present three-storey building was built in 1917 on the foundation of a previous structure and is constructed of granite and red bricks. The first Governor of Hong Kong, Sir Henry Pottinger, resided there from 1843 to 1846. The building then had several owners (including an American trading house and the Russian consulate), and was acquired by the French Mission in 1915 - a name by which it is still commonly referred today. St John’s Anglican Cathedral - this beautiful Cathedral, built in the shape of a cross, is a survivor of the earliest buildings of the British era, built on the only freehold lease in Hong Kong, and is unchanged since it early days. It is the oldest surviving Western ecclesiastical building in Hong Kong, and the oldest Anglican church in the Far East, with construction completed in 1849. It was declared a monument in 1996.
strTitle: Go on a Fascinating Heritage & History Tour of Hong Kong

strIntroduction: This tour is a great introduction to life in Kowloon and the back streets you may not have walked by yourself. We start our guided walk along Hong Kong's historic harbour front, where we introduce the history of Kowloon. Here, well-known Hong Kong landmarks such as the old Railway Clock tower, 1881 Heritage and the Peninsula Hotel are situated. Our guided walk then takes us through the back streets of Kowloon and into the daily lives of local residents. We walk through colourful streets and come across some of Hong Kong’s most lively markets, where you will feel first-hand the energy and soul of everyday Kowloon. As you walk, you will be immersed in the living culture of the Yau Ma Tei and Mong Kok districts - two of the most densely populated spots on earth - and where much of daily life is lived at street level. But also we explain the fascinating history of Kowloon, relating to how it is today. The walk begins at the busy and colourful Flower Market, the centre of Hong Kong's wholesale and retail flower business. The area is chock-a-block with vendors selling all manner of flowers, pot plants, bonsais and more. Next, we walk along Yuen Po Street Bird Garden, a tranquil scene of men and their bird cages. A short walk away is the bustling and energetic Fa Yeun Street Market, selling a wide range of clothes, accessories, electrical goods and food. You'll then visit the Goldfish Market to see the brightly coloured tropical fish and a wide range of aquarium supplies on sale. Hong Kong people believe fish bring wealth, so the market is always packed and a fun place to visit. We also walk past the many pet shops, with their miniature dogs for sale - just the right size for apartment living in Hong Kong. Walking further along we join the throngs at the Ladies Market, where bargain clothes, bags and knick-knacks are available. Then, amid the burning incense coils, you will learn the history of the local Tin Hau temple - Our Empress of Heaven - one of the most popular deities of South China and without question the clear favourite of the boat people, of whom she must be considered the patron goddess. The temple is situated in Banyan Tree Park, where you can watch the local senior citizens playing Chinese chess under the shade of the old banyan trees. This was once the waterfront of Yau Ma Tei. We finish our journey with a walk around the Jade Market, where around 400 stall holders sell accessories made from the revered green stone. The local belief is jade can protect you from evil spirits and calm your emotions, therefore it is often given to children in the form of jewellery. This market is also full of fresh-water pearls.
strTitle: Explore Kowloon's Famous Markets in Three Hours

strIntroduction: Our guided tour starts on the iconic and much loved Hong Kong tram, which commenced operations in 1904. We watch the commuters heading to work, as we rattle along what was once the waterfront of Hong Kong Island and then complete our journey on the MTR (Mass Transit Railway). Walking through Shau Kei Wan wet market, we take in the atmosphere of the daily life of ordinary Hong Kong residents. We commence our hike along a lovely cool path that takes us through shady groves of bamboo and lush woodland, accompanied as we walk by birdsong. We then emerge into open hillsides often covered with wild azaleas or rose myrtle. Our walk follows the rugged undulating spinal ridge of the Dragon´s Back, where the earth is regarded as a living being, with lines of force known as 'dragon veins'. The breathtaking views take in dazzling seas, the distant Nine Pins Islands, sandy Big Wave Bay, Tai Tam Harbour, Stanley and the Red Hill peninsula. We finish the hike by strolling down through shaded tunnels of exotic vegetation, then take transport back to the Central district in Hong Kong. Alternatively, you may continue on to the nearby fishing village of Shek O, with its popular seafood restaurants and beach. The Dragon's Back was hailed by Time Magazine as Asia's best urban hike: "This is the city´s finest and most surprising ramble... The glory of it all is that you're so close to the city, but could hardly feel further away." Walking distance: 5km Grade: moderate Facilities: Toilets en route
strTitle: Go on Asia's best urban hike - Dragon's Back Trail

strIntroduction: Taking in part of the famous MacLehose hiking trail, our guided walk takes us out to the tip of the Sai Kung peninsula, where we make our way to white sandy beaches and clear blue waters, hiking through the remote villages of Sai Wan and Ham Tin in the Sai Kung Country Park. Locally the area is known as Tai Long Wan, or big wave bay, and is a popular surfers destination. Our hike takes us along coastline backed by lush tropical vegetation and forested ridges offering spectacular mountain and coastal sea views. Following a network of paved paths, often on inter-village routes, we pass fascinating old Hakka clan villages. The Hakka farmers nurtured feng shui woods which provide a great breeding environment for native species and we can see many examples of natural reforestation. The Sai Kung uplands and coasts have always been sparsely populated and, from the 1970s, many villagers left their ancestral lands in favour of city lives. The Deserted Beaches Hike offers a unique insight into the homes, lands and beaches these villagers left behind. Although just 20km from Kowloon, this tour will make you feel a world away. Access is restricted to walking or boat. At the end of our walk we can explore the historical village of Chek Keng. Though deserted, it is not truly abandoned as some former villagers occasionally return to check on their ancestral homes. Furniture and cooking utensils stand still in time, as if one day life in some of these homes might be resumed. There is even a Catholic church, built in 1867 - the entire Sai Kung peninsula was converted in the 1860s. But today these sit abandoned. The woodlands behind the village contain stunning bamboo groves, and is home to a great number of fiddler crabs.The wild life today includes the village cows, dogs and passing packs of monkeys that live in the general area. During WWII, villagers in Chek Keng brought items such as old clothes, kerosene, matches and cigarettes to be smuggled into mainland China, where they then bought much-needed food products such as sugar, oil and rice. Walking distance: 11km Grade: strenuous Facilities: Toilets en route
strTitle: Explore the Best Deserted Beaches and Village in Sai Kung

strIntroduction: If you are ready to try some of Hong Kong's authentic local dishes, this tour is for you! This culinary wanderwalk will have five stops; each one handpicked for a special dish. Just bring your appetite! A typical evening starts with a selection of dim sum to fuel your appetite, followed by handmade egg noodles for starters then oyster pancakes and clay pot rice for main, all washed down with fresh local beer or jasmine tea. Our last stop gives you the option to try some traditional sweet treats like red bean soup and sesame dumplings or explore an amazing selection of fusion deserts like ginger soufflé, "burning snow mountain" or chilled mango coconut cream with pomelo.
strTitle: Sample Hong Kong's Authentic Street Food with Local Foodies

strIntroduction: In many cities around the world, the city seems to die down after 6pm and it feels like everybody heads inside. In Hong Kong, it's the complete opposite, where the streets are often filled with throngs of people in the evening, as they socialise, get together for a meal, or shop their cares away... We begin our tour from your hotel before heading towards the heart of Kowloon. Over there, you will get to witness a whole host of fascinating activities, but we will focus on the people on the streets to see what they are up to for the evening. With me charting a path, you will get to see some hidden corners in Kowloon to understand the local night culture. Dinner can be organised if requested. Otherwise I will take you to taste a range of small snacks that are popular with the locals! My goal is show you how us locals live and commute here, as well as what our everyday lives are like. We will be commuting by foot, public transport (subways and buses) and taxis. Rest assured, the cleanliness and efficiency of our world-renowned public transport system will surely take you by surprise.
strTitle: Explore Kowloon by Night with a Knowledgeable Local Guide

strIntroduction: While known as housing the cheapest accommodation in Hong Kong, Chungking Mansions in Tsim Sha Tsui in Kowloon is in fact a fascinating melting pot unique to Hong Kong, featuring guesthouses, curry restaurants, African bistros, clothing shops, sari stores, and foreign exchange offices among other establishments. As a large gathering place for some of the ethnic minorities in Hong Kong, particularly South Asians (Indians, Nepalese, Pakistanis, Bangladeshis and Sri Lankans), Middle Eastern people, Nigerians, Europeans, Americans, and many other peoples of the world, it has been estimated that people from at least 120 different nationalities pass through Chungking Mansions in one years. With this lively mix of guest workers, mainlanders, local Chinese, tourists and backpackers, the Chungking neighbourhood is one of the most culturally diverse locations in Hong Kong, and it would be a shame to leave Hong Kong without paying a visit to this local landmark (where I used to be a resident when I first arrived in Hong Kong) Come and experience the heart of the immigrant community in Hong Kong, and learn about the fascinating stories of this storied place (once featured in Wong Kar-wai's film of the same name). We will also stop for lunch at one of the best Pakistani restaurants in the building for some delicious food!
strTitle: Visit Chungking Mansions with an Ex-Resident

strIntroduction: Negotiating over prices is a favourite pastime of Hong Kong locals, and it's a must do while you're in this colourful city. We will visit the famous Ladies Market in Mongkok, which is famous for the boisterous stall owners and colourful wares. If you're looking for cheap souvenirs, knock-off branded bags, watches, shoes or scarves, this is the place for you. No matter what you're looking for, you will most likely find it at this crazy gathering. The best time to visit the market is early evening, where it starts to get busy. I will take you around the market and show you how to negotiate for the best price! This is a skill you will be able to take with you no matter where you travel to in Asia :)
strTitle: Learn how to Haggle at the Ladies' Market with a Local

strIntroduction: A visit to the Happy Valley Racecourse - the home to Hong Kong racing since 1846 - is a must-visit if you are here on a Wednesday. Here, the locals engage in the city's chief recreational passion - horseracing! The "Sport of Kings," the only legal form of gambling in Hong Kong, is embraced with unbridled fervour by locals. While there's a second racecourse in Sha Tin for weekend meets, nothing beats the adrenaline-charged atmosphere of Happy Valley. As the travel writer Jan Morris once wrote, "Happy Valley on race day is a bitter, brilliant, grasping place." Gambling on the horses is serious business in Hong Kong, with thousands of spectators flocking weekly to the track. Night races are particularly interesting, with bright lights, a frantic atmosphere and big winning payouts. Having previously worked with the Jockey Club, I know the ins and outs of the place and can tell you about the work that goes on behind-the-scenes to organise this massive event every week. Since I am also a bit of a gambler, I can show you how locals suss out the best horses and make their decisions! Depending on your preference, we can either choose the casual beer garden to relax in or pick a VIP experience for dinner, drinks , interactive gaming and a balcony view. It will be a fun night to remember, and you will leave the city a little bit richer in culture, and pocket (with any luck!)
strTitle: Learn to Bet Like a Local at the Horse Races in Happy Valley

strIntroduction: Get away from the hustle and bustle of the big city with this escape to Lantau Island. Lantau Island is the largest island of Hong Kong, yet it has a fairly small population. Most of the island is covered by forests and the only major town is Tung Chung with small villages scattered all over the place. Leaving your hotel at about 9:00, we take a taxi or MTR to Tung Chung, where we take the Ngong Ping 360 cable car up to Ngong Ping village, for a tour of the Big Buddha, Po Lin Monastery and surrounding area (cable car opens 10:00 on weekdays, 09:00 on sat/sun/PH). The twenty-minute cable car ride gives a beautiful 360° view of the mountains of Lantau Island, Tung Chung town and Hong Kong airport. The Big Buddha is the world's largest bronze sitting buddha statue at over 20m in height. The next stop we make is Tai O fishing village, famous for its stilt houses. It is home to several ancient temples. We take a tour around the village and visit the temples, finishing with a 20-minute boat tour of the village and the nearby waters, home to the famous Chinese pink dolphins We then enjoy a leisurely seafood lunch in Tai O, after which we catch a taxi to Mui Wo, a 30-minute scenic ride along the southern shores to the other end of Lantau Island. There we take a walking tour of Mui Wo village and its surroundings (takes 1 1/2 - 2 hours), we visit the Silvermine Waterfall and the beautiful Man Mo Temple. We then take a fast ferry back to Central, returning to your hotel around 18:00.
strTitle: Escape to Lantau Island: Big Buddha & Tai O Fishing Village

strIntroduction: If you've ever been curious to see how regular Hong Kong locals live, come visit the fascinating neighbourhood of Tai Po in the New Territories. Despite the high-rise housing estates for commuters that have sprung up around it, Tai Po still has a countryside feel. While some parts look extremely modern, the centre of the settlement is older and also more lively. Many of the locals have relatives who emigrated to England and elsewhere in Europe during the sixties and seventies - it is partly because of the funds that they sent back, and partly because of the proximity of both the housing estates and the Chinese University of Hong Kong that Tai Po is both a vibrant community and a very pleasant place to visit, even if you are only going to eat there. And really, you should eat there; the same cultural diversity that was mentioned earlier (Yuet, Hoklo, Tanka, Hakka) is reflected in the local food, especially in the town centre, where there are a lot of Hakka! We've got the famous Tai Po Market, one of the busiest and most interesting markets in the New Territories (think of a massive hall of seafood and meat, a huge floor of sundries and then another floor full of delicious cooked food). Towards the northern end of the same street, the double-hall Man Mo Temple is a centre of worship for the Tai Po area. It was founded in the late 19th century and, like the Man Mo Temple found in Sheung Wan, it is dedicated to the gods of literature and of war. The neighbourhood also houses the quaint Hong Kong Railway Museum in the former Tai Po Railway Station, which was built using traditional Chinese architectural design in 1913 and is now preserved as a Declared Monument. This permanent exhibition of Hong Kong's rail history includes photographs, old coaches, samples of tracks, and a full-size model of an electric train compartment, which the kids will love!
strTitle: Explore the Colorful Tai Po Area with a Local Resident
Go on a Street Food Tour with a Local Chef

strIntroduction: How much of Hong Kong do you want to know? Learn about real Hong Kong through interesting stories and fun facts as we comb the back alleys from Central to Western District. For instance, we will show you a place of worship that was “lost and recovered”, check out one of the last ‘survivors’ in Mid levels, and if you are lucky, we may catch some traditional occupations in action (psst… they are always on the move)! How much can you eat? It’s not just egg tarts that we are talking about. Be prepared to savour pork chop buns, Hong Kong style milk tea and many more! To get an authentic feel of life in Hong Kong, our walking tour will skip high-end restaurants and head directly to the Cha Chaan Tengs that are well-loved by locals here! How much can you shop? Whether it’s antiques, porcelain, daily necessities or even famous cooking sauces, we will bring you to lively street markets and shops that locals frequent. Do you know that there are many hole-in-the-wall shops in Hong Kong? We will show you some during your Real Hong Kong Tour!
strTitle: Explore the Real Hong Kong in 4 Hours and Make New Friends

strIntroduction: One thing is for sure, you need your guts here – literally – as we will fill you up both ways. 1) We introduce you to authentic Hong Kong food and, 2) We share with you interesting tidbits of information behind each local gem. The variety of food available in Hong Kong is astounding. For a start, we have the likes of dim sum, egg tarts, barbecued pork and shrimp dumpling noodles. If you are game for it, Hong Kong also offers snake soup, pork liver congee as well as turtle jelly. With so much to choose from, this is the reason why, for our Hong Kong Food Tour, we do not have fixed and compulsory food-stops. Instead of forcing food down your throat (God forbid!) by deciding for you what and how much you will be eating, we think you should definitely have the final say! We look forward to fully customizing a Hong Kong Food Tour for you. Based on your food preferences, dietary restrictions as well as your sense of adventure for exotic food, your enthusiastic Hong Kong Food Tour guide will lead you to discover mouth-watering local delights that have conquered the hearts of millions of Hong Kong people. Not sure what to try? Leave it to us and we will be more than happy to give you an introduction to Hong Kong cuisine that are well-loved by the locals! Worried if you will be the first or last one to finish eating? Fret not about any time pressure, as you set the pace of this Hong Kong Private Food Tour. Unlike a typical group food tour, our time is solely yours and you do not have to worry about matching the speed of other participants. If you prefer to take a break from the amazing food that Hong Kong has to offer, we will gladly help you make full use of your time with us by providing you with other flavours of this exciting country! At Big Foot Tour, we want to immerse you in a real Hong Kong environment. As such, in between food-stops, we can walk through fascinating neighbourhoods that reveal the everyday life of a local. We will fill you in with the history of Hong Kong, explore local cultures as well as share with you some fun facts of Hong Kong! How’s that for a taste of local life and a truly personal culinary adventure?
strTitle: Sample Hong Kong's Best Local Dishes on a Private Food Tour

strIntroduction: The workshop is a 3-hour crash course on how to brew beer at home. All ingredients and equipment will be prepared and set up before your arrival. Introduction to Beer and Brewing Process We will start with a brief introduction to the 4 basic elements of beer and 6 basic steps of brewing. You will see, smell and feel different types of grains. The Brewing Experience 3 to 4 participants will share one set of homebrew kit and start brewing under step-by-step guidance (optional: adventurous participants will be given the option to design and prepare their own recipes under guidance). You will also learn the tricks to homebrewing beer in HK. History of Beer and Craft Beer Appreciation We will tell you how brewers create aromas, colors, flavors and textures from common ingredients. You will also learn to appreciate different beer styles from around the world and how to match the right glass to different beers. Bringing Home Your Homebrew At the end of the workshop, those of you who are staying in Hong Kong for longer will be given the option to bring home your own batch of homebrew, together with a brewing kit (for those of ) to complete the “homebrewing” experience.
strTitle: Learn to Brew Your Own Beer at a Beer Brewing Workshop

strIntroduction: Show-off your dance moves in front HK's beautiful night lights! WHO CAN JOIN? Everyone! Never danced before? No worries! There will be an easy routine for you! An experience dancer? Great! We'll leave space for a freestyle section just for you! WHERE? You will learn the dance at a HK dance studio in the middle of Central (we can get some famous HK egg tarts afterwards!) We will film the dance on the roof of an empty parking lot, with some of HK's landmark buildings with its flashing lights (no joke; they change color) behind you as the backdrop. WHEN? 5pm - 6pm: Learn simple Hip Hop Dance Routine 6:30/7pm - 8pm: Film Dance Really, NO dance experience is necessary. Just come, have a blast, meet new people, appreciate Hong Kong's night time lights, and dance to good music! And if you really struggled through the dancing, we'll finish off with a drink afterwards at a rooftop bar to even better soak up Hong Kong's skyline!
strTitle: Learn a Hip Hop Dance & be Filmed with the HK Skyline!

strIntroduction: The tram has been a mode of transportation in Hong Kong for over 100 years, and you get to party on it with drinks, food, good company, and of course music! This party tram will be about about 2.5 hours through the city streets of Hong Kong. It's everything you can get on an average tour bus and so much more! Get your cameras ready to take photos of the local wet markets, the crowded streets, and the occasional wave-backs at the booming musical tram! Details of the FULL PACKAGE: 4pm - 6pm: TRAM PARTY! Meeting spot will be at "Whitty Street Tram Depot" (Connaught Road West, Western District, Hong Kong - which any taxi driver will know how to get here!). The Tram will take us through HK, including the chic Central, shopping-heaven Causeway Bay, wet-market of Wan Chai. It will turn back around and drop us off again at "Whitty Street Tram Depot" 7pm - 8:30pm: DINNER ON A ROOF! We will all hop in a few little red cars (HK taxis!) to the IFC mall and enjoy THE BEST dim-sum "take-out" from "Tim Ho Wan". We'll bring it up to the roof of the IFC mall in Central and enjoy one of the best meals in the breeze on top of HK's most bustling malls. 9pm - when you feel like going home: SECRET BAR! With our bellies full, we'll head to Wyndham Street to my favorite bar in HK. A little secret location, which will not disappoint. You'll have some of the best cocktails made by HK's best bartenders (a few are internationally ranked!). But shh... you'll find out which bar when you join the group!
strTitle: Party on a Hong Kong Tram with Music and Dancing

strIntroduction: Join us for the most exclusive celebration of the year, the Hong Kong New Year’s Eve Fireworks on Victoria Harbour - guaranteed the best seats in town! Board our intimate and exclusive 70ft yacht, enjoy the open-bar hospitality, hearty food menu, the fantastic night view and the magnificent New Year's Eve fireworks with less than 40 people. Board on our exclusive and intimate 2016 New Year's eve harbour cruise in Hong Kong, inclusive of beverages, 2-course dinner and bubbles. There are less than 40 spaces available so book quickly to get the best and most exclusive experience on offer for New Years Eve. Hong Kong fireworks are renowned for their pyrotechnic excellence, launching from harbour barges and skyscrapers on land. For a New Year’s Eve celebration like no other, celebrate with us aboard our comfortable 70ft cruiser with delicious dinner and open-bar hospitality, whilst enjoying the fantastic night view and build-up to midnight. Every 15 minutes, a shooting star will launch from one of the rooftops of the surrounding buildings. The boat will board from 8:30pm and the countdown display starts from 11:00pm. We will return to the pier at 1:00am. Come and countdown to 2017 with us in style! Canapés - Herbed fish goujons with honey mustard dip - Sage and onion sausage rolls - Tomato, mozzarella and basil bruschetta (V) - Vegetarian spring rolls (V) Mains: - Gourmet handmade beef burgers - Cajun chicken and avocado burgers - Roasted sweet potato black bean burgers (V) - Pan fried king prawns with chilli and lime dressing Sides - Roasted garlic sweet potato mash (V) - Seasonal vegetables (V) - Broccoli and cauliflower gratin (V) - Macaroni and cheese (V) - Fresh bread with butter Desserts: - Cheese board with wafer biscuits - Homemade mince pies - Oreo and Bailey's cheesecake balls Alcoholic drinks: - Prosecco - Red and white wine - A section of beers - Mulled wine Throughout the trip... - Stem ginger candy (just in case it's a bit choppy) - Gourmet teas and coffees
strTitle: Celebrate New Year's Eve on a Victoria Harbour Cruise

strIntroduction: For Cantonese people, "yam cha" (literally 'drink tea') is is inextricably linked to the Chinese tradition of drinking tea. Early farmworkers would head to their local tea house to revive with tea and good conversation. Ken Hom, American-born Chinese chef, and himself states that the best dim sum and chefs are found in the Canton region, and I could not agree more! City Hall, one of the last places in Hong Kong to still use server trolleys, is a unique and tasty setting to enjoy your first ever dim sum lunch. It is also right next to the Star Ferry pier, so you can hope on a ferry ride after this experience to explore Tsim Sha Tsui and beyond! The atmosphere in traditional local restaurants can be somewhat intimidating if you don't speak Cantonese, so if you've never gotten a chance to try dim sum in Hong Kong before, come with me and I'd be glad to help you pick out some delicious dishes! Some of my favourites are shrimp and pork dumplings (siu mei), pork buns (cha siu bau), taro pastries (wu gok) and dessert of egg tart (dahn ta) or mango pudding (mun gwa pu ding). If you are feeling adventurous, we can even dig into some spicy chicken feet! As a popular guide in Hong Kong, I'd also be happy to share tips on where to go and what to do during your time here! Note: This price excludes the cost of food and transport. We will likely order a number of dishes and split the bill! Photo credits: thecitynomad.com julianaloh.com thetemptedpalate.typepad.com
strTitle: Have an Authentic Dim Sum Lunch with a Local Guide

strIntroduction: This tour is completely flexible, so you can choose from a variety of styles - street photography, food photography, documentary photography - anything that helps you capture the city your way! During your time with me, I'll show you around the places I know might suit your request and we'll find ways to help you get the best shots of your time here! Some of cool places I've photographed: - Yim Tin Tsai (abandoned island near Sai Kung) - Lamma Island - New Territories (Kam Sheung Road) - Streets of Kowloon and Hong Kong (Sham Shui Po, Kwun Tong)
strTitle: Hang Out with a Photographer and Capture HK at its Best

strIntroduction: If you're looking to score the hottest tickets in town, you're in luck as I have 4 tickets to the most popular event of the year that I need to sell as I will be away. MORE ABOUT THE HONG KONG SEVENS: Firmly established as the world's premier event of its kind and one of the most popular annual sporting events in Asia, the Hong Kong Sevens attracts some of the world's greatest rugby players and thousands of fans from every corner of the globe to the magnificent Hong Kong Stadium every year. With fast and furious rugby action combined with a carnival atmosphere and world rugby's largest prize purse, the 2015 Hong Kong Sevens will be an unforgettable three days for everyone there. This year's tournament is extra special as it marks the Hong Kong Rugby Football Union's commemorations of 40 Years of Sevens in Hong Kong. From kicking off with 12 teams in front of 3,000 people at the Hong Kong Football Club in 1976 to today's three-day extravaganza of international rugby revelry with 28 teams playing in front of a total of 120,000 spectators, the 2015 Cathay Pacific / HSBC Hong Kong Sevens is "Where the World Comes to Play." A raft of initiatives and entertainment is on the cards for spectators and around the world in 2015 as the rugby world again focuses on Hong Kong in March. History: http://hksevens.com/about-us/40-years-of-the-sevens NOTES: 1. These are general admission tickets with free seating. However, I would advise early queuing for the South Stand which gets full very early. 2. For Sunday: Gates open 07:00am, Cup Final at 19:00pm, presentation and fireworks finish at 19:40pm. 3. The face value of tickets are different as on Friday there will be around 2 hours of rugby action whereas Sunday is a full day of rugby plus the finals and cup ceremony. 4. PICK UP: must be on either 26th March or 27th March 2015
strTitle: Buy Hong Kong Sevens Tickets 2015

strIntroduction: Chinese New Year is without doubt the biggest and most adored festival of the lunar calendar. The 26 minute firework display at Victoria Harbour is renowned for its pyrotechnic excellence, launching from harbour barges and skyscrapers on land for breathtaking entertainment. For a Chinese New Year’s celebration like no other, celebrate with us aboard our comfortable 80ft yacht with dinner and open-bar hospitality, whilst enjoying the fantastic evening with other guests. A usual New Year tradition is to gift red packets or envelopes with gifts , so each guest will receive their own Lucky red packet with gifts and discounts from local outlets. Passengers of all ages are welcome. NOTE: The fireworks are scheduled to kick off at approximately 8pm this year, so we will meet at about 6.00pm at Central (further details will be provided once you have made a booking) DINNER MENU (Included in your ticket price): Appetisers: - Steamed egg, asian meatballs, dumplings Dinner - Shrimp and mango salad - Roasted suckling pig - Sweet & spicy glazed spare ribs - Sweet and sour fish - Yeung chow fried rice - Asian chicken salad - Asian vegetable noodles - Mixed vegetables with garlic - Chinese greens with oyster sauce Dessert - Fruit and cakes
strTitle: Hong Kong Chinese New Year Fireworks Cruise 2016

strIntroduction: You too can have your own Jane Goodall experience. It's not everyday that you get to see monkeys, especially in Hong Kong. But I know where they are. I've found their secret hangout spot. It's an easy/moderate hike on paved road, maybe 30 - 40 minutes give or take, in the mountains just beyond Kowloon. There will be uphill walking, so be prepared. But you will be rewarded as we reach the top. The best time to see them is late morning, 10 - 11 am. Please do not bring food!! They might harass you if they smell food in your bag. After the hike, we can have lunch at a local cha chaan teng (optional).
strTitle: Discover Hong Kong's Hidden Monkey Mountain!

strIntroduction: This lunch journey isn't about snacks or street food. It's the real deal, full on meal. So you better bring your appetite, I mean it. Starting in Sham Shui Po, we will first have a unique Hong Kong cha chaan teng-style egg and beef sandwich. Next, just a few blocks around the corner, we wash that down with tasty handmade dumplings swimming in a bowl of rich Shanghai style fish broth. After, we'll walk towards Prince Edward, a place where we will eat juicy meat-stuffed "pie," characteristic of northern Chinese cuisine. Try the curry mutton too if you're game. And if you're a fan of spicy food, we well venture to this one stall that serves freshly cooked wontons in a spicy sauce. Then finally, let's stroll down to Mong Kok, where we'll finish off with something sweet... a tall glass of ice cold milk tea, a classic egg tart, and a warm "pineapple bun," pork chop inside optional. And if you're still not full (which I can't imagine how), there are always more places to eat, like dim sum, beef noodle soup, hainan chicken rice, congee... Now doesn't that make your mouth water, cause it's sure doing it for me. :) You will have to pay for your own food but don't worry, these places are cheap, especially since we'll be splitting the check and sharing the food. It shouldn't cost more than $200 HKD total per person, unless you go completely nuts! We'll be walking from one restaurant to the next. This'll help us digest the food, which we'll need badly... :)
strTitle: Pig Out on Local Hong Kong Dishes with a Hungry Foodie

strIntroduction: The tallest peak in Hong Kong is Tai Mo Shan, towering at 962 meters high above Tsuen Wan to the south, and Tai Po to the north-east. This mountain, with its steep slopes, also boasts herds of feral cows grazing as well as Hong Kong's tallest waterfall - the Main Fall of the Ng Tung Chai cascade of waterfalls with a 30-meter free fall. The tour starts at Tsuen Wan MTR station, from where we take a taxi to our starting point, the highest point of Route Twisk, and about halfway up the mountain. Hiking from there along a scenic route, first a dirt track and later a paved road, we steadily climb up, enjoying the sweeping views along the way. The summit itself can not be reached as a wireless station has been built up there. From the top we continue slowly down towards Sze Fung Shan, until we turn left to the steep path down to the Ng Tung Chai waterfalls. There are a total four large falls in this cascade, the highest being the Scatter Fall, the Main Fall, the Middle Fall and finally the Bottom Falls. Finally we hike down via Man Tak Yuen, a Buddhist monastery, and Ng Tung Chai village to Lam Kam Road from where we take transport back to Tai Wo MTR station. This hike takes about five hours, and includes some steep ascents and descents running over mostly well maintained trails. Proper footwear is a must. The total ascent is about 500m as the starting point of the hike is halfway up the mountain.
strTitle: Conquer the Tallest Mountain and Highest Waterfalls in HK

strIntroduction: We start our night out around 7 or 8pm, depending on your schedule. I will bring you to one of my favourite local 'dai pai dong', or outdoor eatery, where you can savour a variety of Chinese dishes. We hang out here for an hour or so to soak in the atmosphere before we proceed to the first of our 3 or 4 spots for the night. Depending on the sorts of places you like, we can choose from underground jazz clubs to more edgy outdoor bars. If you are new to the city or just visiting for fun and want to meet other locals like myself, I can even invite my friends along to say hello. After we hop into a few places, we can stop by my favourite supper place for more local hangover cures!
strTitle: Explore HK's Coolest Underground Bars with a Local

strIntroduction: Hong Kong has one of the world’s most impressive natural harbours. Stunning buildings and landmarks on Hong Kong Island and Kowloon adorn both sides of the busy harbour, a variety of craft including ferries, junks, sampans, cruise ships, freighters and tankers. Getting on a traditional Junk boat is a must-do activity in Hong Kong. Join me as I take you on a leisurely day cruise from Causeway Bay to Lamma Island or Clearwater Bay in Sai Kung. On this special day, it will be all-you-can-eat and drink, with an opportunity to swim in the sea (or to the beach) and partake in other water activities.
strTitle: Enjoy a Day Cruise on a Traditional Junk Boat

strIntroduction: The Lion Rock is one of the best recognisable mountain peaks from Hong Kong. Looking from Kowloon or Hong Kong Island to this peak it is easy to recognise the lion shape. This hike takes you up to the head of the lion, which, at 495 metres high, is the best viewpoint of Hong Kong overlooking Kowloon and Hong Kong island to the south, and Sha Tin and Tolo Harbour to the north. From this viewing point, we'll be able to see the nearby Amah Rock, which resembles a woman carrying a child (the story goes that this was a fisherman's wife who stood there every day to see whether her husband came back from the sea, and got struck by lightning and turned into stone) While there are so many options for hiking in Hong Kong, this might be the very best viewpoint in Hong Kong! Come along with me as I bring a group of hikers up to one of my favourite spots!
strTitle: Take in the Best View in Hong Kong from Lion Rock

strIntroduction: This tour shows you both cultural and historical sides of Taiwan in a day trip. Exploring Jinguashi, Jiufen & Pingxi, you can meet the local miner to learn the history of Jinguashi, visit the spectacular Golden Waterfall and Yin-yang Sea, Make your own sky lantern and wander narrow streets of Jiufen --- a town famous for having been an inspiration for the Miyazaki classic Spirited Away. This tour includes pick-up from your accomodation, so you don't need to worry about the transportation. Enjoy your trip in Taiwan and make an unforgettable memory! [Schedule] 09:00 Pick up from your accommodation 10:00 Meet the experienced miner 10:30 Visit the ruins of the 13 Levels 10:50 Golden Waterfall and Yin-yang Sea 11:30 Hidden spot - best view of Jinguashi 12:00 Lunch in Jiufen (at individual's expense) 14:30 Shifen old street in Pingxi 15:00 Make and send your own lantern 17:00 Drop off at your accommodation
strTitle: Jiufen and Pingxi Day Trip

strIntroduction: Food culture is very important in Taiwan. A lot of activities we partake in are related to eating. I would therefore like to introduce you to Taiwan as seen through a culinary lens. There's an endless list of cuisines to try in Taipei and it's impossible to taste everything, so I will bring you to my favorite area and hopefully you will enjoy this yummy journey with me. Take your time, walk slowly, and you will find this area fascinating and full of fun. Here is a suggested itinerary, but we are always able to adjust it to your personal preference. 11:00 AM: Meet at your hotel and go for lunch. ↓ 13:00 PM: Walk around Yongkang Street, which is famous for creative shops and cuisines that attract both locals and foreigners alike. I will introduce you to my favorite French restaurant where you can have a cheap but really delicious Crème Brûlée. ↓ 15:30 PM: Take a break and have a cup of tea or coffee. We can speak about any topic that you are curious about such as culture, food, people, travel experience etc. etc... ↓ 16:30 PM: Visit CHIANG KAI-SHEK MEMORIAL HALL to check out traditional architecture or do some shopping. There are many types of shops (books/food/art/music/local brands) and I can make recommendations depending on what you'd like to visit. ↓ 18:30 PM: Back to food! You can't say you visited Taiwan if you've never been to a night market here. Have dinner in one of the night markets and try many kinds of local dishes. ↓ 20:30 PM: Last but not least, local supermarkets would be fun to visit! See what the locals are buying and buy some for your next day as well.
strTitle: Explore Taipei: Restaurants, Shopping, Markets & More

strIntroduction: Tainan is the old capital in Taiwan where you can find several important historical sites. The temple is an important place of worship for locals in their daily lives. I would like to show you some significant temples in Tainan city. Get ready to be amazed by the fascinating stories behind each temple. Here are the 3 temples we will visit. All the temples listed are designated national historical sites, which attract many devotees and visitors every year. - Tainan Cheng Huang Temple (城隍廟) - Tainan Da Tain Hou Temple (大天后宮) - Sacrificial Rites Martial Temple (祀典武廟) During this experience, you will learn about: - The architecture of the temples - Stories of gods and goddesses we see - The meanings behind the wall paintings - Taiwanese religious practices I will also point out some Taiwanese street food along the way. Let's have a feast for the soul and stomach together!
strTitle: Learn the Architecture & History Behind 3 Temples in Tainan

strIntroduction: はじめての台南、リピーターの方、それぞれ行きたいスポットが違いますよね。 主要観光スポットから、ここに行ってみたいというご要望に合わせて、あなたにピッタリの台南の観光プランを無料で作成し、現地でご案内します 提供内容 内容：台南の街をご案内します。 時間：約6時間(10:00〜11:00スタート) 人数：１名様～※団体様のご案内も可能ですのでご相談ください。 事前に教えていただきたいこと ・観光開始時間 ・移動手段(タクシー、タクシー貸切、マイクロバス貸切) ・当日行きたい場所 ・当日したい事 ・お食事についての希望 ・現地集合場所
strTitle: 古き良き街台南を満喫！６時間コース！観光地、お食事全て選択可能！

strIntroduction: Tea culture in Taiwan is very rich and it has a long history. Get familiarize yourself on this Tea Culture Tour and enjoy the lush greenery of tea farms! Ascend into the lush mountains just north of the city on the Maokong Gondola and get the opportunity to meet highly skilled local tea experts who will teach you how to steep the perfect pot of tea. Explore the local mountain villages and take in the incredible views of bucolic tea farms and the one of a kind Thousand Island Lake. You need not worry about the language barrier because an English tour guide will attend you through the whole trip! This tour starts by picking you up from your accommodation in Taipei City. Get on the Maokong Gondola where you can get the panoramic view of the gigantic forests full of beautiful trees. After the Gondola ride, learn the rich background of Taiwanese tea and gain a deeper understanding of the authenticity of it. After lunch time, your guide will take you to Thousand Island Lake. Thousand Island Lake is a very big alpine lake and the views over the lake and surroundings are simply beyond description. After that, you'll take a walk through the tea fields. If you visit in a tea picking season, which normally is Spring, you even get to experience the traditional tea picking. Finish this day tour with actually tasting tea and learning tea ceremony in the tea house. A tea ceremony expert will teach you everything you need to know and help you through tea ceremony. Why don't you spend a day learning about Taiwan's rich and old tea culture and appreciating the beauty of it? Tour Schedule – 09:30 Pick up from your accommodation – 10:00 Maokong Gondola – 10:30 Explore the background of Taiwanese Tea – 11:50 Lunch time – 13:30 Thousand Island Lake – 14:30 Take a walk through the tea fields – 15:30 Tea taste and learn tea ceremony in the tea house – 17:30 Drop off at your accommodation
strTitle: Tea Culture Day Tour and A Tea Ceremony In The Tea Fields

strIntroduction: This 1 day tour covers various unique activities that you can experience in Taiwan! If you join the tour, you can know the history and culture of Taiwan, visit beautiful and gorgeous historical places, wander narrow streets around Shi Lin night market, and explore one of the tallest buildings in the world! In this tour, we'll visit touris attractions including: - Longshan Temple - Presidential Office Building - Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall - Taipei 101 - Lin An Tai Historical House - The Grand Hotel (Pass by) - Yangmingshan National Park - Beitou Hot Spring Area - National Palace Museum - Shilin Night Market [Schedule] 09:00 Pick up from your accommodation 09:30 Longshan Temple 10:30 Presidential Office Building 10:50 Chiang Kai-Shek Memorial Hall 11:30 Taipei 101 / Lunch 13:00 Lin An Tai Historical House 13:40 Pass by The Grand Hotel 14:30 Yangmingshan National Park 15:30 Beitou Hot Spring Area 16:00 National Palace Museum 18:00 Shilin Night Market (Drop off at MRT Jiantan Station )
strTitle: Enjoy Taiwan's Top 10 Tourist Attractions in 1-Day Tour!

strIntroduction: It's not about knowing where to go, but knowing what to order. At the most popular night market of Taiwan-- Shilin Night market, I will guide you to make sure you get to try all the main local Taiwanese street food you need to try during this tour. Other than that, you will also get some shopping done for pretty much everything you need from clothing to souvenirs.
strTitle: Shilin Night Market: All-in-One Food Tour

strIntroduction: 初めて台湾へ旅行する方にもリピートの方々にもおすすめできる人気観光地「九份」への行き方は電車は公共バス・タクシーを乗り継いで行くこともできますが、距離があるため乗り継ぎの手間や運行時間を考えるとバスツアーで行くのが圧倒的に安心便利です。 16:45 民芸品店「金龍藝品」集合 ガイドがお出迎えします。 18:00頃 九份到着。郷土料理の軽食 石畳の道沿いに小さなお店や建物が軒を連ねる赤提灯で照らされた九份を散策しながら、夕食をご堪能いただきます。 観光時間は約60分を予定していますので、町並み散策や夜景鑑賞などをお楽しみください。 20:00頃 饒河街夜市を経由（自由行動） 九份を観光するなら寄らない人はいない！というくらいの人気スポット饒河街観光夜市(ナイトマーケット)にも立ち寄ります。400m続く一本道、その両脇に所狭しと並ぶ屋台では、ここでしか食べられない台湾のローカルフード、ここでしか味わえない絶品グルメが夜市に並びます。。全てを味わい尽くすのは無理！というくらい豊富で、きらびやかな夜をお楽しみください。 五分埔へは行き方の案内のみとなり、立ち寄りはありません（希望者は途中解散可） 21:30頃 解散。 ※解散場所は車内でガイドよりお客様にお伺い致します。 下記から降車地をガイドにお伝えください。 ①饒河街夜市現地解散 ②台北駅まで送迎 ③MRT松江南京駅まで送迎、 ※20%OFF割引が適用されるツアー実施日は下記です。 1月15日 ~ 2月28日 ※上記日程以外のツアー日程をご希望の方は通常の10%OFF価格オプションをご購入くださいませ。
strTitle: 20% OFF 異国情緒たっぷり！夜の九份(きゅうふん)観光＆夜市散策（日本語ガイド/送迎/夕食付き）

strIntroduction: 07:30頃 各ホテル出発 混載車にて台北駅へ向けて出発します。駅から列車に乗り換えて花蓮へ。約一時間の旅となります。到着後、混載車にて太魯閣渓谷を観光します。 12:00頃 昼食 ローカルレストランにて郷土料理のランチを堪能していただきます。 大理石工場見学（約40分） →アミ族の踊りを見学頂きます。 混載車にて花蓮駅へ 向けて出発。列車に乗り換えて台北へ向かいます。 18:10頃 ホテルへ送迎 ※交通状況によって変動する場合がございます。

strIntroduction: 16:45 集合 民芸品店「金龍藝品」に集合していただきます。集合地から混載車にて台湾市内のレストランに向けて出発します。 17:30 夕食 台湾市内のレストランで夕食となります。 グリーンワールドキッチン(洛碁廚房)にて小籠包をお楽しみください。 ※お食事内容、レストランは予告なく変更になることがございます。 18:20 十分へ出発 19:30 十分にて天燈上げを体験 天燈は1~4名で1個となります。願い事を書いて空高く飛ばしましょう！ ※天候が悪い場合は老街散策となります。 20:30 移動 寧夏夜市へ移動し、夜市を散策していただきます。グルメやショッピングをご堪能ください。 グルメの中でもおすすめは - 賞味期限20分!?のフレッシュパパイヤミルク「木瓜牛乳」 - 台湾の名物デザート レモンゼリー「愛玉加檸檬」 - 牡蠣オムレツ「鶏蛋蚵仔煎」 などがあります。 21:30 夜市到着後、現地解散（ホテルへの送迎はありません）
strTitle: 十分で楽しむ夜の天燈上げ＆夜市散策（夕食付き）

strIntroduction: 07：45頃「出発」 台北市内中心部の主要ホテルより出発します。 乗合車での移動となりますので、時間厳守でお願いいたします。 ＜散策コース＞ ・行天宮 ・お茶セミナー ・総統府 ・中正紀念堂 ・民芸品店 12：00頃「昼食」 台湾料理の三大人気店の「春梅子」にて台湾料理を楽しんでいただきます。 食後、 ・故宮博物院 ・忠烈祠 ・漢方セミナー（別途料金で足つぼ案内） という順で回ります。 16：45「解散」 民芸店「金龍」にて解散します。
strTitle: ランチも楽しめる台北市内観光！

strIntroduction: 09:00 「出発」 台北市内中心部（主要ホテル）より淡水に向けて出発します。 「淡水観光」 紅毛城、古町散策、關渡媽祖宮など、台北中心とはひと味違う台湾を堪能していただきます。 ※月曜日は紅毛城が休みのため、代案地へご案内致します。 12:00 「昼食」 ローカルレストランにて、郷土料理をお楽しみください。 14:00 「帰着」 台北市内中心部（主要ホテル）に送迎いたします。
strTitle: 海辺の街「淡水｣を日帰りで満喫！観光ツアー

strIntroduction: 07:40 ホテルシーザーパーク台北入口前集合 or 08:10 グリーンワールドホテル松江ロビー集合 9:00頃 九份到着 九ふん散策をたっぷりご堪能ください。 12:00頃 軽食 台北市内にてB級グルメの軽食を味わっていただきます。 13:30頃 お送り 台北市内のホテルに限り、各ホテルへ送迎いたします。
strTitle: 半日で堪能！軽食付き九ふん観光

strIntroduction: 07:40-08:10 指定ホテルより出発 お客様が滞在しているホテル（指定のホテルのみ）へお迎えに参り、混乗車にて九ふんへ出発します。 (約1時間)。到着後、街並みを散策していただきます。 観光後、台北市内へ向けて出発します。 12:00 昼食 牛肉飯などの軽食ランチを予定しております。 13:00 三峡観光 東洋芸術の殿堂である祖師廟、老街、鶯歌（陶器街）を観光、散策していただきます。その後、民芸品店へ移動します。 17:30 市内レストランにてご夕食 フカヒレラーメンのフルコースをご用意しております。 19:00 指定ホテルお送り
strTitle: 九ふん•鶯歌•三峡観光ツアー（絶品フカヒレラーメンのディナー付き）

strIntroduction: ご希望の時間でホテル出発 予約状況やお店の開店時間によりますが、お客様のお好きな時間帯でご予約いただけます。 ご予約時間に到着するよう、お客様のご滞在ホテルまでお迎えに参ります。 足つぼマッサージ開始 マッサージ時間約30分となっております。 ホテルへの送迎 終了後、ホテルへお送り致します。
strTitle: 本場の足つぼマッサージ体験（30分）

strIntroduction: 16:30 民芸品店「金龍藝品」に集合していただきます ※お客様ご自身にて集合場所までお越し下さい。 17:30頃～ 乗合車にて金龍藝品より出発し、鼎泰豊到着 特別なコース料理をご賞味いただきます。 19:00頃～ 士林夜市へ移動 約40分間夜市を散策していただきます。 20:00頃～ 乗合車にてお客様をホテルへご送迎いたします。 ※士林で更なる散策をご希望の方は現地解散も可能です。
strTitle: 小籠包と言えば！で有名な鼎泰豊でディナー（士林夜市散策付き）

strIntroduction: ■松山空港→ホテル お客様のフライト到着時間に合わせて、係員がお出迎えいたします。その際、お客様のお名前が書かれたボードを持っておりますので、目印としてください。 合流しました後、お客様のホテルに向けて出発いたします。 ※ホテルチェックインはお客様ご自身にてお願いいたします。
strTitle: 松山空港からホテルまでの送迎サービス！(片道専用)
